Award.AwardTitle: Structural Equation Modeling with a Small Number of Observations (N) and a Large Number of Variables (p)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will develop structural equation modeling (SEM) methodology that can be applied to data with a small number of observations (N) and a large number of variables (p). The new methods will broaden the applicability of SEM to important areas of research where the number of observations may be quite small, such as data from hard-to-reach populations. Data and methods for data analysis are key to advancing science. SEM is used by many disciplines, including psychology, education, sociology, management, health sciences, and medicine. Existing SEM methodology requires the number of observations to be proportional to the square of the number of variables. However, it may be difficult to collect the large number of observations required by SEM to reach reliable conclusions. The new methodology is expected to yield reliable results when N is either larger than 30 or two times the number of variables. The research has the potential to both improve data analyses and reduce data collection costs. The methods will be implemented in freely available, user-friendly software.

With small N and/or large p, existing methods for SEM face four major practical issues: (1) near singular sample covariance matrices and the related issue of nonconvergence in parameter estimation; (2) inefficient parameter estimates with non-normal data; (3) unreliable model test statistics; and (4) inaccurate standard errors. The project will address the first issue by adding a proper diagonal matrix to the sample covariance matrix or the ridge method, an approach that has been shown to be effective. The other issues will be addressed by a new method termed empirical modeling, in which the empirical behavior of a test statistic/standard error is modeled under a variety of conditions. By combining empirical modeling and the ridge method, the project is expected to produce efficient parameter estimates and reliable model inference.

Institution.Name: University of Notre Dame
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

POR.DRECONTENT:
Structural equation modeling (SEM) is a major methodology for analyzing survey and non- or quasi-experimental data. It has been widely used by researchers in psychology, education, sociology, management, health, etc. While many variables can be observed via survey or questionnaires in these fields, most researchers face the challenge of collecting enough observations due to a limited budget. The aim of the NSF project is to develop reliable methods for model inference in SEM with many variables but not a sufficiently large sample size.

Our developed methods yield much more efficient parameter estimates than existing methods (normal-distribution-based maximum likelihood or an asymptotically-distribution-free generalized least squares) for typical data in social sciences and health. That is, we can get the same accurate parameter estimates when the sample size is much smaller.

Our new statistics yield much more reliable results for overall model evaluation than existing statistics, especially when the number of variables (p) is large while the sample size (N) is not large enough. In particular, with the normal maximum likelihood method, the sample size N needs to increase at the speed of the cubic of p in order for the test statistic to yield reliable model evaluation. Our new statistics can still yield reliable model inference even when N is about 2 times of p. With many variables, our formulas also yield much more accurate standard errors than those obtained from the widely used sandwich-type formulas.

Our results/study also clarified why conventional methods for SEM fail when many variables are involved. We proposed the method of empirical modeling for dealing with issues caused by large p and small N. Our results imply that empirical modeling not only works for SEM with many variables but is also an effective method for statistical modeling with big data that are characterized by large p in general.

Four graduate students participated in the proposed research and published their work in professional journals. Two of them will be assistant professors starting the fall of 2018, one is currently an instructor in a research university, and one became a biostatistician in a drug company.

In addition to contributing to cutting-edge methodology and training professionals in data science, the developed methods will benefit all the communities where SEM is used directly or indirectly via free software WebSEM (https://websem.psychstat.org/wiki/) in which most reliable methods were implemented. Our results also have the following consequences:

  • They reduce the cost for researchers in areas where it is expensive to collect a large enough sample sizes (e.g., longitudinal studies, drug abuse). Therefore, it can make the previously impossible studies feasible.
  • They increase the scope of applications of SEM to areas where the target population may not be large enough in the first place (e.g., problem behavior syndrome, psychological aspects of living with a fatal disease).
  • Our new modeling methodology, empirical modeling, is rather easy to use and will facilitate other quantitative researchers to develop valid methods for real data that are not normally distributed or when the number of variables is large and N is small.

Last Modified: 08/01/2018
Modified by: Ke-Hai Yuan
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Structural equation modeling (SEM) is a major methodology for analyzing survey and non- or quasi-experimental data. It has been widely used by researchers in psychology, education, sociology, management, health, etc. While many variables can be observed via survey or questionnaires in these fields, most researchers face the challenge of collecting enough observations due to a limited budget. The aim of the NSF project is to develop reliable methods for model inference in SEM with many variables but not a sufficiently large sample size. Our developed methods yield much more efficient parameter estimates than existing methods (normal-distribution-based maximum likelihood or an asymptotically-distribution-free generalized least squares) for typical data in social sciences and health. That is, we can get the same accurate parameter estimates when the sample size is much smaller. Our new statistics yield much more reliable results for overall model evaluation than existing statistics, especially when the number of variables (p) is large while the sample size (N) is not large enough. In particular, with the normal maximum likelihood method, the sample size N needs to increase at the speed of the cubic of p in order for the test statistic to yield reliable model evaluation. Our new statistics can still yield reliable model inference even when N is about 2 times of p. With many variables, our formulas also yield much more accurate standard errors than those obtained from the widely used sandwich-type formulas. Our results/study also clarified why conventional methods for SEM fail when many variables are involved. We proposed the method of empirical modeling for dealing with issues caused by large p and small N. Our results imply that empirical modeling not only works for SEM with many variables but is also an effective method for statistical modeling with big data that are characterized by large p in general. Four graduate students participated in the proposed research and published their work in professional journals. Two of them will be assistant professors starting the fall of 2018, one is currently an instructor in a research university, and one became a biostatistician in a drug company. In addition to contributing to cutting-edge methodology and training professionals in data science, the developed methods will benefit all the communities where SEM is used directly or indirectly via free software WebSEM (https://websem.psychstat.org/wiki/) in which most reliable methods were implemented. Our results also have the following consequences: They reduce the cost for researchers in areas where it is expensive to collect a large enough sample sizes (e.g., longitudinal studies, drug abuse). Therefore, it can make the previously impossible studies feasible. They increase the scope of applications of SEM to areas where the target population may not be large enough in the first place (e.g., problem behavior syndrome, psychological aspects of living with a fatal disease). Our new modeling methodology, empirical modeling, is rather easy to use and will facilitate other quantitative researchers to develop valid methods for real data that are not normally distributed or when the number of variables is large and N is small.
